driver_type: Multiple "cannibal" Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) from the massive active region AR13664 (15 times the size of Earth) which merged into a single "super-shock" that hit Earth at 17:05 UT on May 10
notes: Kp=9; Often referred to as the May 2024 (Mother’s Day) superstorm

driver_type: The disturbance was caused by a full halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) associated with an X1.1 solar flare from Active Region 3614 which erupted on March 23
notes: Kp=8 (NOAA scale); unusual FD with fast recovery reported across NM network

driver_type: The storm was caused by a full-halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) associated with an M1.7 solar flare that erupted on April 21
notes: This was the most intense geomagnetic storm since the 2015 "St. Patrick's Day" storm until it was surpassed by the May 2024 extreme event

driver_type: A high-velocity "cannibal" CME from an M7.1 flare (sunspot region AR2891) that overtook slower preceding eruptions
notes: The storm reached a maximum Kp-index of 8- and produced vibrant auroras visible as far south as New Mexico and California

driver_type: This event was driven by the strongest flare of Solar Cycle 24—an X9.3 flare from Active Region 12673 on September 6—which launched a fast-moving halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) with speeds exceeding 1500 km/s
notes: Reported as G4 severe storm; Dstmin listed as −142 nT (quick-look) in event overview

driver_type: A series of five halo or partial-halo CMEs reached Earth over six days mostly originating from active region AR 12371 which produced several M-class flare
notes: Often called the 2015 Summer Solstice Storm; Dst ≈ −198 nT (Kyoto provisional cited in aviation impacts deck)

driver_type: An X1.4 solar flare from Active Region 1520 launched a fast halo CME with an initial speed of 1285 km/s
notes: Reached a G4 (Severe) level with a minimum Dst index of -139 nT and a Kp-index of 7

driver_type: This event was driven by a pair of powerful eruptions from Active Region 11429 including an X5.4 and an X1.3 flare on March 7
notes: Global Total Electron Content (TEC) variations were observed and the storm significantly compressed the magnetosphere

driver_type: A magnetic filament eruption around 01:00 UT on October 22 propelled a halo CME toward Earth at speeds exceeding 2 million mph (approx. 900 km/s)
notes: The CME contained a "knot" of southward-pointing magnetic field (\(B_{z}\)) which allowed solar wind plasma to penetrate deeply into the magnetosphere

driver_type: An X3.8-class solar flare from Active Region 930 launched a fast CME (estimated at over 1700 km/s)
notes: This occurred during Solar Minimum surprising researchers with its intensity during a normally quiet phase

driver_type: The event was triggered by a series of powerful flares from Active Region 10808 most notably the X17.0 flare on September 7 which launched a fast shock reaching Earth with a mean velocity exceeding 1100 km/s
notes: This period featured severe magnetic storms during a cycle minimum; the activity triggered blackout of high-frequency communications potentially affecting emergency workers in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina

driver_type: This "extrastorm" was driven by a series of solar eruptions including a doublet of solar flares and associated Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) from a narrow longitudinal sector that remained active throughout the summer
notes: Stunning auroras were reported globally; becoming visible as far south as Spain and Arizona in the northern hemisphere

driver_type: The event was triggered by an X1.2 solar flare from Active Region 759 on May 13 which launched a halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) that impacted Earth roughly 33 hours later
notes: The intense interaction significantly weakened Earth's magnetic shield temporarily allowing more cosmic rays to reach the ground than would be possible under normal magnetic conditions—a process that actually competes with the "sweeping" effect of the Forbush decrease

driver_type: The event was caused by a very fast Interplanetary Coronal Mass Ejection (ICME) and shock wave that hit Earth’s magnetosphere at ~17:11 UT on January 21
notes: The South Pole neutron monitor registered a count rate increase of 5600% (a factor of 56) in just 6 minutes—the largest ever recorded at that location

driver_type: A powerful X2.6 flare from the extremely active region AR 720 on January 15 launched a fast halo CME toward Earth
notes: The interplanetary magnetic field (IMF) reached nearly 20 nT providing the magnetic "shield" that swept away galactic cosmic rays

driver_type: Active Region AR 10696 produced dozens of flares and multiple halo CMEs. The specific storm on November 9 was driven by the arrival of a CME associated with an X2.0 flare observed on November 7
notes: The storm caused the auroral oval to expand down to 55° latitude and destroyed the tertiary ozone layer at roughly 77 km altitude in the northern hemisphere

driver_type: Active Region AR 10696 produced a series of powerful eruptions. Three sudden commencement (SC) pulses were recorded on November 7 as shocks from multiple Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) impacted the magnetosphere
notes: The November 7 2004 event marked the beginning of a sequence of "superstorms" during the declining phase of Solar Cycle 23 characterized by a significant Forbush decrease (FD) that reached its deepest point over several days

driver_type: This event was caused by a full-halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) associated with a series of active solar regions crossing the Sun
notes: The geomagnetic storm of July 26–27 2004 triggered a severe Forbush decrease (FD) recognized as one of the largest and most well-documented cosmic ray modulation events of its decade

driver_type: The event was triggered by a fast-moving CME associated with an M6.1 solar flare that erupted from Active Region 540 on January 20
notes: The storm reached a G3 (Strong) level on the NOAA Space Weather Scales with a maximum Kp index of 7

driver_type: An M3.9 solar flare from Active Region 501 launched an exceptionally fast CME with an estimated speed of 2850 km/s
notes: The NMDB network showed a deep sharp profile caused by the extreme compression of the magnetosphere and the intense magnetic field of the passing ejecta

driver_type: Active Region 10484 produced a "cannibal" CME from the X17.2 flare (the second largest of that cycle) which overtook previous eruptions
notes: The October 29–30 2003 Forbush decrease was one of the most violent and deep cosmic ray modulations ever recorded occurring during the peak of the legendary "Halloween Storms."

driver_type: An X17.2 solar flare (one of the largest in history) erupted from Active Region 10484 on October 28 launching the primary CME responsible for the October 29 impact
notes: The October 29 2003 Forbush decrease was the opening phase of a historic "double-drop" event during the Halloween Storms representing one of the most significant cosmic ray modulations of the space age

driver_type: Active Region AR 10365 was exceptionally volatile producing multiple solar flares and at least three halo CMEs on May 27 and 28 that merged or interacted before hitting Earth
notes: The decrease was triggered by the arrival of two interplanetary shocks at the L1 point on May 29. The first arrived shortly before noon UT and the second hit around 18:30 UT each causing a successive dip in cosmic ray counts

driver_type: The event was triggered by a fast-moving halo CME associated with an M1.0 solar flare from Active Region 10191 on November 14
notes: This was a typical "step-like" decrease. An initial minor decline began on November 15 followed by a sharper primary drop on November 16 as the core of the Interplanetary Coronal Mass Ejection (ICME) engulfed the Earth

driver_type: This event was triggered by a fast halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) associated with an M5.0 solar flare from Active Region 9948 on May 22
notes: Researchers noted significant north-south anisotropy during the onset meaning the decrease was felt differently at polar stations depending on their orientation relative to the ecliptic plane.

driver_type: The disturbance was linked to an M2.3 solar flare and a halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) observed by SOHO/LASCO on April 17 interacting with earlier eruptions from April 15
notes: The storm caused extreme plasma heating (up to 3000 K) in the F-region and a deep decrease in electron density at middle and high latitudes

driver_type: The period was remarkably calm. The Dst index remained between -28 nT and -43 nT. In space weather terms a Dst above -50 nT is typically considered a "weak" or "quiet" condition
notes: The December 30–31 2001 event featured a unique Forbush decrease (FD) that occurred during a geomagnetically quiet period making it a rare example of a "recurrent" or "quiet-time" cosmic ray modulation

driver_type: The event was triggered by a fast halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) from Active Region 9704 which erupted alongside an M9.9 solar flare on November 22. The CME traveled at approximately 1437 km/s
notes: The November 24 2001 event featured a distinct Forbush decrease (FD) driven by one of the final extreme geomagnetic storms of the Solar Cycle 23 peak

driver_type: An X1.0 solar flare erupted from sunspot region AR 9684 on November 4 launching a powerful halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) with a speed of roughly 1810 km/s
notes: Vibrant red and green auroras were visible as far south as Florida Texas and California in the United States as well as across Central Europe

driver_type: On October 19 giant sunspot AR9661 erupted twice producing two identical X1.6-class solar flares. Each flare launched a halo CME toward Earth with speeds exceeding 700 km/s
notes: The flares caused a significant R3 (Strong) radio blackout on the sunlit side of the Earth and affected HF communications across the Pacific

driver_type: The event was triggered by a minor Coronal Mass Ejection (CME) or a high-speed solar wind stream associated with the active solar regions present on the disk at the time (Regions 09653 and 09658)
notes: The October 11 2001 event featured a minor Forbush decrease (FD) following a period of moderate solar and geomagnetic activity during the peak of Solar Cycle 23.

driver_type: A massive solar flare erupted on September 24 2001 (at 10:40 UTC) which was pointed almost directly toward Earth. This flare launched a fast-moving halo CME with ionized gas clouds that reached Earth within 24 hours.
notes: The storm caused vibrant auroras at lower latitudes and significantly interfered with high-frequency (HF) wireless communications

driver_type: The event was triggered by a fast-moving halo CME that erupted from a complex active region on the Sun
notes: The dynamic pressure of the solar wind increased by a factor of 10

driver_type: The event originated from Active Region 9415 which unleashed a powerful X2.3 solar flare on April 10. This flare produced one of the fastest halo CMEs of Solar Cycle 23 with a linear speed of 2411 km/s.
notes: The arrival of the shock caused a Storm Sudden Commencement (SSC) at roughly 13:43 UT about 30 minutes after the initial shock was recorded at the L1 point.

driver_type: The event was linked to the arrival of an interplanetary shock driven by a halo Coronal Mass Ejection (CME). This occurred just days after the sun unleashed the largest solar flare ever recorded (an X20-class on April 2)
notes: The storm generated high-velocity particles causing R4 (Severe) radio blackouts on the sunlit side of the Earth earlier in the week with secondary effects continuing through the April 8 window
